photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/247322.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My kids love enchiladas and request them for every birthday dinner. I use a clove of garlic instead of powder. I don't reserve any of the mixture. I fold it into the chicken and put a small amount along the bottomish of the tortilla, sprinkle with cheese and roll it up. Before I place them in a casserole dish, I coat the dish with green enchilada sauce. Once the dish is full, I cover with more sauce and cheese. I bake it off & garnish with green onion and serve them with a little sour cream. I cut fat and calories when I can, too. This makes one 11x13 dish & one 8x8, which I reserve for dinner the following day.

text:
As written I can't rate it very high.  The sauce just tastes like a  canned soup casserole. (We've all been there.)  But I added a medium size jar (about 24 oz - maybe a bit less) of Salsa Verde to the soup mixture.  (Medium spiciness for me.)  And that really makes for a yummy sauce.  I also changed to corn tortillas and threw in some sauteed zucchini and corn, but the main thing is tweaking that sauce.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is a nice alternative to the traditional red sauce enchiladas.  Although I do like the traditional red sauce, I have to limit my intake of tomato sauces due to heartburn.  The only changes I made was to double the sauce and substitute yellow onions for the green onions.  I also used fresh minced garlic instead of powder.  These substitutions helped to give the sauce more flavor.  I used 8" flour tortillas and it made 12 enchiladas with plenty of filling and topping!  The 12 enchiladas fit nicely into a 9 x 13 glass baking dish.  My husband and 10 year old son LOVED it!  We almost ate the whole thing ;).

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was fabulous! I invited my parents and brother over for dinner and they went crazy for it and want me to make it again for them soon!

I made some modifications: I swapped flour tortillas for 12 small white corn tortillas. NOTE: You must fry the corn tortillas in vegetable oil so that they won't fall apart when you roll them. Also, I used 1% milk,  light sour cream, and a tri-cheddar blend rather than one variety of cheddar. Lastly, I used shredded chicken instead of cubed. (I had about half of a chicken I had roasted the night before leftover and just used that.) 

For those commentators saying they doubled the sauce recipe, I found the amount of sauce to be just right, so long as you spread it with a spatula over the enchiladas and make sure to not to overcook the sauce. Then again, I don't typically like my food swimming in sauce, so it's really a matter of taste.

I might try this recipe with jalapeños next time for a bit of an even spicier kick.

city:

country:
None
text:
Very yummy recipe!  I did modify it some to fit what I had on hand, and learned a few silly lessons in the process.  1) Instead of canned green chiles (couldn't find any), I minced up a fresh jalapeno.  Word to the wise--don't taste the seeds!  Yeah, I did that.  Ouch.  2) I made BBQ Pork for Sandwiches from this site the night before, and reserved some of the pork before putting the BBQ sauce on.  Used it for the enchiladas.  Worked out great!  3) I bought burrito-sized flour tortilla shells--probably about a foot in diameter!  Much too large--I put 1/6 of the filling in one, and realized I wouldn't be able to make six of them.  So I made four instead, and cut them in half when I served them.  Overall, very yummy!

I made some changes to the recipe to give it more flavor, since my family found them to be pretty bland.  I tripled the onions and sauteed a couple of cloves of minced garlic.  I added a cup of salsa to the sauce as well.  I plan on baking the chicken with some taco seasoning or chili powder to add some intensity to the flavor.  The are more like burritos than enchiladas, but they are a good start for a basic recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious!  I saute'd some frozen grilled fajita chicken strips in a little bit of oil and sprinkled them with southwest spices ( I used Tastefully Simple's Fiesta Dip spice).  I definitely used corn tortillas (enchiladas are made with corn and burritos are made with flour) and softened them by dipping them in a little heated oil.  I doubled the sauce.   I was out of green chiles and onions, so instead I saute'd minced fresh garlic and minced dried onions in the butter and I added at least a teaspoon, maybe more, of chile powder and ground cumin to the sauce.  I used high grade white Wisconsin Cheddar (from Costco) for the cheese and it was insanely flavorful!  After assembling I sprinkled the enchiladas with paprika which added another flavor and some kick.  My kids and husband raved about them!

text:
This is an excellent recipe and became an instant hit with the family. Reading through some of the other reviews I did increase the sauce between 1/4 and 1/2. The chicken should be increased to 2 cups and the cheese should be increased as well.  After doing these increases I was still only able to fill 5 ten inch shells instead of the 6 twelve inch shells it calls for. Guess you could use smaller shells and just have more of them.  Really, really good though.  You won't be disappointed

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1696451.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe! Not too spicy to serve to my little girls(five and 2) but enough flavor for my thirteen year old son. I used leftover roasted chicken which had McCormicks Herbs de Provence on them, but not an overpowering taste. I mixed in cooked Vidalia onion(half a small one), 4 garlic cloves minced and sauteed with onion, and a can of rinsed black beans to the sauce and spread half in my Crockpot. I filled the burritos(small taco size) with chicken mixed with a Mexican blend(had yellow cheddar in it) and slightly thawed frozen yellow corn. After rolling all of the burritos up and lining them up in the Crockpot, I covered with more sauce and Kraft's blend of Mexican all white cheese. Also I had used a larger(35%) can of Campbell's Cream of Mushroom in the sauce so they wouldn't dry out in Crockpot. I cooked on high for two hours and served with sour cream and chopped black olives. Before serving, I mixed some McCormicks ground chipotle pepper into the sauce that i put over my son's, husband's, and mine but not for the girls, because as my two year old would say, "It's too bicy!"(spicy).

Very good! My husband doesn't like the traditional red sauce.  I use both flour and corn because it's different texture. text:
Scaled this for 8 enchiladas, using 2 cans green chiles, 1/2 large onion (sauteed), a cup and a half of sour cream, 1 can of condensed cream of chicken and a can and a half of milk to thin it as the tortillas absorb a lot of liquid when cooking. This recipe is very flexible, flavorful and a family favorite. I can stretch the chicken with leftover rice, corn and/or beans and its still a delicious and fairly fast dinner that my family loves.

text:
I'm giving this 3 stars based on the way the recipe is written. 4 stars with my adjustments.  I took other reviewers suggestions and made some changes.  I doubled the sauce but kept the chicken the same amount.  I added a can of corn (drained and rinsed) and a can of black beans (drain and rinsed).  In an attempt to feed a family of 6 on a budget I always try and stretch our dollar !  I added some taco seasoning to the filling and to the sauce I added 1 19 ounce can of red enchilada sauce.  Again trying to streeeetch the dollar !  I did find the cream of mushroom soup taste a bit off putting but it wasn't terrible.  Next time I might use cream of chicken like others had suggested.  This is an excellent dish to put together quickly and store in fridge or freezer for later on in the week.  Thanks teppij !!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/13561.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This didn't taste BAD, but I really wish I had read the reviews before making. The sauce needs to be doubled & thinned with more milk or stock/broth, more chicken needs to be added (or some other filler; corn, beans, bell peppers, etc), and I would definitely recommend smaller tortillas. I added extra chicken, and still barely had enough filling for 4 tortillas. I doubled the milk, and still didn't quite have enough sauce to cover the enchiladas. Sauce should be put under the enchiladas; the tortillas were very tough on the bottom. The mushroom flavour was almost overpowering. To compensate, we added fresh cilantro to the sauce, and topped with fresh avocado, & salsa. It was alright. I could see this being a good dish to cook for picky kids. Fairly mild as written.

I had to change this up to suit our picky needs. I cooked chicken in crock pot all day with some beef broth, onion pdr, garlic, pdr, chili pdr, salt and pepper. Turned out delicious and super moist. GREAT, thanks for sharing. This is what I did different. I used corn tortillas microwaved under a damp paper towel for 30 sec, used minced garlic in place of the powder. Used cream of chicken (all that I had on hand). Used chopped jalapenos about a 1/3d cup. Had about a cup or so of store bought hot salsa, added that.

The meal was a hit. The wife and kid even did the clean up for me if I make it again this weekend.

Easy to make. Tastes great = 5 stars

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and was very pleased.  Made a few changes that others might find useful.  I used fresh chopped garlic instead of garlic powder and sauteed them with the onions.  Like many other reviewers I went with corn instead of flour totillas, just seem to make more sense.  Since I like spicier dishes I used (2) 4 oz. cans of Ortega 'Hot' diced chilies (they really arn't that hot).  Also used 1 cup of caned sweet kernal corn, this added a very nice texture and the flavor blended well with the chilies.  Instead of milk I substituted heavy cream, what can I say I cook for flavor and not for my health.  I would definitely make this again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy.  I agree with previous reviews that the sauce should be doubled and some spices added (oregano, cilantro, etc).  Regarding the tortillas, I too prefer the corn, and there's an even simpler way around the problem of making them pliable.  I make *layered* enchiladas, building them like lasagna.  I do spray the corn tortillas with nonstick cooking spray or brush them with a little olive oil, because they taste better that way.  Then layer in the baking pan as follows:  enough sauce to just cover the bottom, then the flat tortillas, sauce, cheese, repeat.

userID:
2644516
Display Name:
Silentchimes
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! But I will admit that I change several ingredients...I substitute a few cloves of garlic for the onions (my pregnant tummy can't stand onions!), and heat chili powder and cumin with them in the oil (per another reviewer's recommendation). I also substitute a chicken stock roux for the cream of mushroom soup (that stuff is pretty bad for you). I also substitute canned beans (black or kidney) for some of the chicken, to save money. But I love the method for this recipe and always use it to help me put together my enchiladas!

Rating:
5

1

userID:
2345797
Display Name:
babychase3
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3788006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was quite good!  I've never made chicken enchiladas and I was impressed with the results.  I omitted the green chiles (not a fan of spicy food and had none on hand either).  I doubled the ingredients at the suggestion of other reviewers.  I sauteed the green onions in butter as directed and simultaneously browned my chicken in the butter as well.  I seasoned the chicken with paprika, onion and garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and black pepper.  I used 1 can of cream of mushroom and 1 can of cream of chicken with my cup of sour cream.  I also added a splash of chicken broth and a can of rotel to the sauce.  I browned my white corn tortillas in extra virgin olive oil before assembling my enchiladas.  All in all, the dish came out out very good.  Will definitely make again! :-D
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-11-23T09:43:36.627
helpfulCount:

text:
These enchiladas were ok...I prefer red sauce, so that's probably why I didn't enjoy them as much as everyone else.  (too creamy for my taste)  I didn't have the green chiles, so used diced japs instead, giving the perfect amount of heat.  Would have been way too bland without them.  I'm unsure if I liked the cream of mushroom soup or not.  Will prob use all sour cream next time and add cilantro because they were missing a little "flavor."  Perfect for people that like milder dishes.

I can't eat tomatoes or many of the spices that are in traditional Mexican food.  These enchiladas hit the spot when I am craving something a little Mexican.  I leave out the green chilis and substitute a couple dashes of cayenne pepper for heat.  They are so good - even my picky husband likes them!  If you like, for extra flavor you could add a packet of taco seasoning to the chicken.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my third review ever! Highly worth trying at least and recipe could stand on it's own without adjustments IMO. I have ate MANY forms of enchiladas in my life, being from just North of the Mexican border. I typically make enchiladas with corn tortillas like others have mentioned but there is a trick to making these enchiladas less "soft" or 'burrito like' without the hassle of frying corn tortillas. Lightly brush the rolled  flour enchiladas with some olive oil before pouring mixture on them. Bake for 7ish minutes, remove and then pour mixture over it with added cheese and bake for remaining time. Gives it more hardness without overdoing it. I doubled this recipe and was able to make 20 no problem using soft taco shells. I also used chicken breast slow cooked for 2 hours in a mixture of adobo seasoning and a packet of 'white chicken chili' seasoning with 1.5 cups of water covered with foil in the oven at 355. I would definitely make this again, this has become my new favorite enchilada recipe!!!

text:
My family and I love this recipe.  I did make some changes though and we typically double the recipe because everyone loves the leftovers.  We use 1 can FF cream of mushroom soup and 1 can FF cream of chicken soup.  We also use light sour cream and 2% chedder cheese.  In my opinion, you can't tell the difference when using the lighter ingrediants and it saves so many calories and fat. Sometimes to spice it up a little I will add 1 can drained rotel to the chicken mix.  We serve with rice and it makes an excellent meal!

text:
I was very skeptical of the high rating on this recipe.  I'm used to tomato-based enchiladas, so the ingedients seemed a little weird to me.  Boy was I ever wrong, these are the most delicious enchiladas ever, the diced green chiles really pull the flavors together.  I followed the recipe exactly and the smell as it was baking was wonderful, my next door neighbor asked if she could come over for dinner.  And this recipe makes wonderful leftovers, as with a lot of dishes, the flavors just get better when they are allowed to set overnight in your refrigerator.  Take them to lunch the next day, you'll be the envy of your coworkers.

text:
I have made a dish simular to this one. I used ground beef and after I was done browning the beef I mixed Salsa in with the beef. I then rolled the beef mixture into flour tortillas and placed them in a cassarole dish. I mixed cream of chicken soup with sour cream and green chilis and poured it over top of the tortillas. I then baked it for 30 mins and then added cheese on top and baked it until the cheese was warm and bubbly. this is a very good recipe and its not too spicy. Perfect when you have little kids who will be eating it also like I do!!

text:
This was delicious, definitely a dish I will make again.  Based on the many reviews of it, I did make some changes to the recipe.  For the chicken, once it was cooked, I added chicken taco seasoning to spice it up.  I doubled the sauce and used cream of chicken instead of cream of mushroom.  Then, instead of adding milk to the sauce I added 3/4 C salsa.  I covered the pan while cooking for the first 30 minutes then uncovered for the last five.  It was great to serve along with my beef enchiladas so our guest had a choice of chicken or beef.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2010-02-15T18:29:59.19
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4281056
Display Name:
Tiffany Joe
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
376
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3896184.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Definitely a favorite. I cheated big time, and made modifications as well based on the reviews. We hate corn tortillas so flour tortilla enchilada/burritos were fabulous. Plus, I cheated on the prep and used my crock pot. I used 1 can of cream of mushroom (98% reduced fat), 1 can of cream of chicken (98% reduced fat), 1 can of green chiles, and 1/2 packet of fajita seasoning, 1/2 cup of Light sour cream, 1/3 cup of diced onion, 1/2 cup of non-fat milk, mixed all together thrown in crock pot. I used 2 large boneless/skinless chicken breast halves, threw them in the crockpot frozen. Cooked on HIGH for 3.5 hours, stirring occasionally. Added 1 cup of mexican flavored shredded cheese variety to the soup mixture, removed chicken and shredded it with 2 forks then returned to the crockpot for 30 minutes while I prepped the tortillas (microwaved for 1 minute with water spritzed on them). I sprayed(with non-stick spray) a casserole dish, poured some chicken flavored spicy rice on the bottom of the dish, and then rolled the chicken/soup mixture in 6 /8inch flour tortillas. Placed them seam side down, then covered with remaining soup mixture, and chunked cheddar and mozzarella cheese. Placed in the over for 15 minutes. VIOLA a family favorite. Even my picky, won't eat any type of mexican food husband loved these. He's happy to take them to work tomorrow for leftovers. Served with a little salsa, and sour cream.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe, although not perfectly authentic (corn tortilla=enchilada, flour=burrito). I used leftovers from a rotisserie chicken and it turned out great!  A few adjustments based off taste and what was on hand:  We like it spicy, so for a doubled recipe, I used the 2 cans chiles plus 1/4 cup of Red Devil sauce, 1 can cream of mushroom and 1 can cream of cheese, cut the cheddar cheese down to 1.5 cups, and did everything else as written.  12 enchiladas and 5 people, but they all went!  Many hands make filling and rolling easier.  Also, be sure to heat the tortillas so they don't crack--toss them in the microwave with a wet paper towel for 30 seconds, or heat with a little oil in a cast iron skillet.  Buen provecho!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was my first time making Enchiladas as my husband is not a big fan of Mexican food.  I tweaked the recipe a bit as I found that the filling is not enough for 6 pieces of tortillas. First for health reasons, I substituted the butter with olive oil.  Upped to 2 cups of shredded chicken breast meat and 2 cloves of garlic instead of garlic powder.  Also added a cup of diced sweet onion.  When I realised that the filling was not enough for even 4 pieces of tortillas, I added a cup of mixed peas and corn to the filling at the last minute.  Delicious! Sorry tyeppij, I also had to up the baking time to an hour as 35 minutes was way too short for the sauce to thicken.  My husband gives this recipe a 5* (I have yet to tell him what exactly this recipe is, for right now, he has been told it's called "Chicken Wrap"!)

text:
Read the reviews before I made this and saw that several people didn't have enough filling so I went very sparingly on how much I put in each tortilla wrap thinking I could stretch it and I was only able to come out with five.  The taste is very good but every bite had too much tortilla and hardly no filling.  Next time I make it I think I will have to triple the filling to fill them the way an enchilada should be or use the smaller tortilla wraps not sure which.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a few changes and it came out really good! My husband who is hard to please told me it tasted like restaraunt style enchiladas!    I added 3/4 cup chopped green bell peppers and sauted that with the green onion for about 4-5 minutes until the bell peppers were tender. Instead of using cream of mushroom soup I used one 24 oz can of green enchilada sauce.  In the sauce mixture I added the 10 oz of the enchilada sauce and also put 1 cup shredded cheddar cheese into that and (and also what the recipe alls for).  The rest of it I pourd over the top of the enchiladas when they were rolled up and placed in the pan.  Then I used 1 cup shredded cheddar cheese and mozerella cheese and sprinkled that ontop of the enchiladas and baked for 25 minutes!    Yum!  I hope this helps anyone! I will definitely make this one again!

text:
These were very good! A very different twist on enchiladas, but we enjoyed them. I did fry my tortillas in vegetable oil before assembling the enchiladas because I just can't get enough of that fried, crispy tortilla taste. I can watch calories some other day. I used fresh garlic and added a generous amount of cumin.  Instead of only using 1/4 of the sauce in the tortillas, I combined the chicken and cheese with all the sauce and used ALL of it inside them. I poured green enchilada sauce on top of the rolled tortillas, then added the shredded cheese. Very good. Thank you :)

text:
Love this recipe! I cannot eat Enchiladas in Mexican Restaurants anymore. I have tried with both the flour tortillas and the white corn tortillas. Either way it is fabulous. The flour is a little bit creamier and blends in with the sauce. While the corn stands out. When I used the corn I warmed them in a pan until the bubbled and then dipped them in heavy whipping cream. I did not have a can of green chilies so I went ahead and chopped up some pickled peppercinies, yellow banana peppers. and sweet cherry peppers. The cherry peppers added a nice splash of red. I also added some Monterey Jack cheese to the top and pepper jack cheese to the filling.

userID:

Display Name:
scandalex
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was amazing! But of course, I made a few of my own changes. To start off with, I used white corn torillas. I heated a bit of olive oil in a pan, and cooked each side of the tortilla for just a few seconds to soften them. In place of the green onions, I used mushrooms to taste. For the sauce I used half cream of muchroom soup and a half can of cream of chicken. When adding the sour cream, I used half sour cream, half cream cheese (that turned out much better than you'd think)! When adding cheese, I added it throughout the cooking process, to taste. I topped the enchiladas with half cheddar and half pepper jack. I only had to bake mine at 350º for maybe 10 - 15 minutes, and cranked the oven to about 400º and cooked for another 5 minutes or so. Thanks for a good recipe!

text:
SOOOOO GOOD!!!!!  I did make a few changes and it was absolutely perfect and packed with flavor!!  This is officially in my rotation of favorite meals.  

My changes:  I cooked the chicken with some taco seasoning, I added a half can of enchilada sauce instead of the milk, I used jalepenos instead of chiles for more spice, and I doubled all of the sauce (except for the jalepenos) and used one can cream of mushroom and one can cream of chicken.  If you have not yet, you must try this recipe!!

text:
I give it 4 1/2 stars.  It was a pretty simple recipe that my whole family loved.  I cut up a whole chicken, rubbed with taco seasoning, baked with a bit of chicken broth at 350 degrees for 1 hour and shredded it.  This gave it more flavor than plain chicken would have had.  The only other change was to use cream of chicken soup instead of cream of mushroom.  Served with corn and a salad.  It's still not overwhelming in the flavor department, but it is very satisfying.  There were barely any leftovers.

text:
Wow - one of my top ten recipes ever. A few things: (1) this isn't really an enchilada recipe, more like a cream sauce burrito. (2) I have no idea how this could be six servings - I had exactly enough for four normal-sized enchiladas. (3) I essentially made no changes to this recipe, and it turned out flawless. These are NOT messy, NOT complicated, NOT hard to eat... I actually made them ahead of time, too, so it would be a good recipe for guests. I served with black beans and homeade tomato salsa, to balance out the creaminess of the enchiladas. This recipe rocks.

None
text:
With a few changes this is a five star recipe. I used cream of chicken soup instead of cream of mushroom, added 1 Tablespoon of chili powder, pinch of cayenne, 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1/2 cup of salsa to the filling and 3/4 cup of salsa to the topping. Rotisserie chicken would be great, shredded up in the filling, or I just cooked 3 breasts in some oil and sprinkled them with garlic powder, chili powder, salt, and pepper. This made 8, filled, 6 inch tortillas. I used the salsa instead of the steps with the green onions and can of green chilis.

text:
Tastes very good and is easy.  Recipe needs to be adjusted a little bit, however.  If using a 13 x 9 dish, you need to use no more than a 10 inch tortilla, the 12 inch called for by the recipe will not fit in the dish.  I used seven 8 inch tortillas, which filled the 13 X 9 perfectly, with maybe room for one more if I would have proportioned the filling a little bit better.  My 12 year old daughter made this and did an excellent job.  This is a good recipe for someone just starting to cook.

text:
I use this recipe pretty frequently and never get any complaints from the family.  I have learned not to use left over smoked chicken in them, as there just aren't enough robust flavors in this recipe to stand up to the smoky flavor.  I always use about 1/2 c more cheese than the recipe calls for.  These enchiladas seem to be better the next day.

text:
My family loved this recipe, although I made several changes, some following others' directions.  I used shredded chicken and seasoned it with taco seasoning.  Then I used 1 can cream of chicken soup and 1/2 can cream of celery soup and more cheese than suggested as I like cheese.  Also, to make this mild enough for my small children, I left out the onions and peppers and instead used 1 tbsp each of sage, crushed red pepper, chili powder and garlic powder, all mixed in with the sauce.  My husband said it tasted just like the enchiladas at our favorite mexican restaurant.  Also, we served with salsa and sour cream on top.

text:
Hi ...
Okay ... my Enchiladas turned out absolutely fab fab fab ... BUT, I made definite changes ... otherwise, I feel that the recipe would have been too boring ... here's what I did ...
firstly, I used Amy's Mushroom soup ... it is semi-condensed ... I purchased it at Whole Foods ... I used an entire can of chopped green peppers ... along with the 'juice' ... I used a small can of sliced olives ... I simply included in with sauce ... I poached the chicken in chicken broth with bay leaves and other spices according to taste ... I sauteed fresh garlic with the green onions ...I added lots of red pepper flakes, and HOT salsa to the sauce ... I used CORN TORTILLAS not flour tortillas (yuck) ... I simply sprayed the bottom of the dish with non-stick spray which worked beautifully ... the corn tortillas turned out soft and fab ... otherwise, I followed the recipe to a tee ... oh ... I didn't add milk at the end because the sauce was thin enough since Amy's mushroom soup is semi-concentrated and more watery than the fully concentrated kind ... otherwise I pretty much followed the recipe to a tee ... I must tell you, the enchiladas were absolutely fab fab fab ... OH ... I forgot, at the end ... after rolling my enchildas and etc., putting on the cheese topping, I put a little hot sauce on the top of the dish ... I know, it sounds like too much hot stuff ... but, trust me, it isn't !!!  We had glasses of fab chardonnay (chilled) and toped the enchiladas with fresh green onions and t

text:
Very tasty.  Using a rotisserie chicken made this dish a snap to put together.  This dish is versatile - one can add their own special touches.  I made extra sauce and used only about 1/2 of the green chilis.  I added salsa for extra flavor and color.  Served with the usual condiments - sour cream, salsa, chopped green onions, tomatoes and olives, etc.  Next time, I may add a little mexicorn and/or rinsed black beans to the filling.  The only drawback was that the enchiladas were soggy the next day :((. Delicious and easy to make - what more could you ask for?

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good, I did do a few changes based on other's reviews.  I first sauted the chicken in onions and garlic, I then added Taco Seasoning, and shredded the chicken and added water, covered it and let simmer for 25 minutes.  I added cilantro and green pepper to the butter/green onion mixture.  I doubled the sauce recipe, and used 1 cream of chicken soup and 1 cream of mushroom soup.  In the filling mixture, I added white long grain rice along with a diced tomato.  Instead of 1/4 cup milk I added 1/8 milk and 1/4 of the seasoned water that the chicken was cooked in.  Turned out great, just the kick it needed.

text:
Whenever I make these enchiladas, I add a can of cream of chicken soup.  Also, I add an extra can of green chiles and about 1/4 tsp of cumin.  This helps make it go a little farther and a little more favorable.  I use whatever filling I have leftover in the bowl to top the tortillas with before I bake them.  Then, I had the Cheddar cheese to melt for about 5 minutes before they are finished.

text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe as written and gave the recipe three stars. I have made it again with my changes and it's now a 5 star recipe.  In fact my husband said it's the BEST enchilada he has ever had.  The changes I made:  I added diced jalapenos, cumin, cayenne, and a can of original rotel to the sauce mixture. (omitted the chiles) I added the milk to 3/4 the sauce, but I don't think that was necessary.  These enchiladas now have a wonderful flavorful real Mexican kick!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As others have advised, this is a spectacular base when the sauce portion of the recipe is doubled. I have been cultivating this recipe for about three years now and have found it best with twice the green chillis, fresh garlic to taste (I prefer quite a bit) a blend of fontina and asiago cheeses lightly sprinkled inside of the tortilla (corn or flour depending on prefernce) and half of the mexican blend cheese on top. Cilantro adds incredible flavor to this dish as does a handmade tomatillo sauce I often create for mexican dishes. You can buy these at the store. Utilizing a rotiserrie chicken is a fantastic way to time save, in my experience. Remember when making this recipe that it is a fantastic foundation for your creativity. Tweak it to your taste and enjoy. I believe whole heartedly that is predominantly the reason it has received the reviews that it has.  When cooked according to recipe I find the enchiladas to be on the bland side. Again, do not be afraid to spice it up.

country:
None
text:
Just for a quick note.  The recipe has you preserving 3/4 of the sauce and adding milk.  First of all I am a big fan of cheese, and not crazy about browned/blackened sauce all over the top of these beautiful enchiladas.  I often reserve only 1/8 of the sauce and cut the amount of milk in half (use whole milk) then coat every inch of the pan w/cheese.  Bake it the same until bubbly like the recipe says, and you can make more enchiladas and waste less sauce.  I also subsitute 2/3 a can of Rotel Hot Green Chiles/Tomatoes and it reall "kicks it up a couple notches!" :-)

I made a few changes, but this was delicious.  Instead of adding the first 4 ingredients, I used 1/2 package of taco seasoning mix and cooked with the meat per package directions. I added the sour cream to the soup, however I also put a strip of sour cream on each tortilla. I did not add the cheese to the saucepan; I sprinkled it directly into each tortilla on top of the sour cream. I then added a small amount of soup mixture (soup, milk and sour cream) to the chicken and placed the chicken mixture on top of the cheese in each tortilla. I then finished as stated in the directions. Very creamy with just a touch of Mexican flair.

text:
This is so good. I've added it to my recipe box and get asked to make it all the time from my husband and four boys. I do double the sauce because we like the tortillas soft and I put some sauce on bottom to keep them from getting too hard. I also add some Zatarans blackened seasoning to the chicken to give it a kick.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is superb. I made it for the first time and it did take a little longer to prepare and to make the sauce but i am sure i will be faster next time. 

substitions:
I couldn't find canned chillis, i wasn't keen on chopping my own either so i used jalapenos - 2 tbsp. just 2 tbsp made it quite spicy already.

i added in fresh sliced mushrooms. i added it in together with the chicken and  let it simmer for a while until it starts to soften. i didn't let it soften entirely because i knew i would be placing it in the oven.

i added more milk to this because it didn't seem like i had enough sauce for 6 tortillas.

i think adding herbs gives it a good twist. i added chopped, basil, parsley and coriander and when i served i dribbled some chopped spring onions.

everyone at the table loved this. it came out nice and moist - most importantly full of flavour even though i added about 1 cup of milk to it.

definitely a keeper!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband is the pickiest eater, and he is very skeptical of homemade enchiladas.  I made these last night and he devoured them and asked me when I would make them again.  We absolutely LOVED this recipe!!  Thanks so much for helping me find a dish my picky eater would love!!  EDIT:  My husband still prefers the original written recipe but I prefer a little extra ingredients.  I always add fresh chopped cilantro and jalepenos.  For a more aunthentic sauce I still reserve 1/2 of the sauce like it says to do before you add the chicken and cheese.  But I combine it with a sauce I made in the blender.  Here it is.. to a blender or food proccessor add: *1/2 red bell pepper *1/2 can of diced green chilies *1/2 jalepeno, chooped *1/2 tomato, chopped *3 cloves of garlic *3 TBS fresh chopped cilantro *Squeeze of fresh lime juice *1 TBS cumin *1 tsp corriander *Drizzle of olive oil  blend it up and then mix it in with the reserved sauce.  Pour over enchiladas and then use 1 cup FRESH grated cheddar cheese + montery jack cheese

text:
This was a very good recipe!  Made it for my boyfriend and we both liked it alot.  I really would give it just 4 1/2 stars since it was tweaked a bit, and without the jalapenos it seemed like it'd be bland. Like others have suggested, I doubled the sauce recipe.  Used one can of low-fat Cream of Mushroom, one of low-fat Cream of Chicken, since that's what I had.  I couldn't get the green chiles, so I subbed 3 jalapenos, finely chopped (I do love spicy!) but next time I'll just use 2. I also forgot the milk but didn't really miss it.

I covered half the enchiladas with the traditional red enchilada sauce and the other half with the sauce from this recipe.  Both were delicious, but I think I prefer the red a bit more.  All in all, a very tasty and interesting recipe.  Careful, though--very rich and very filling.

These were really good.  If you like creamy enchiladas, you will love this recipe! I doubled all of the ingredients except for the tortillas and it made enough for probably 5-8 people depending on how many sides you offer with the meal.  I added one can of the chicken verde along with the cream of mushroom soup and it turned out wonderful.  I will definitely use this recipe again!

My husband and I thought these were great!  I doubled everything except the tortillas, as others had recommended.  I left out the green chiles (I'm not a fan of them), and added chili powder and cumin.  Also, I sprinkled some taco seasoning on the chicken before cooking it and then shredded the chicken instead of cutting it into cubes.  I also wanted to use up some leftover tomato I had, so I added a little bit to the inside of each enchilada.  I'll definitely make these again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these a couple dozen times in the last few years.  One thing I've learned is that it's better if you double all ingredients for filling and sauce.  When I haven't doubled the recipe (except for the tortillas), there just doesn't seem to be enough filling or sauce and the enchiladas can end up kind of dry.  If you like your food spicier, I would add a can of diced jalepenos to the filling. This recipe is a great base to experiment with according to your family's tastes.  I've also made this with low-fat sour cream, soups and cheese, and it came out great.  Thanks for a family favorite!

text:
this tasted pretty good.
i fried my chicken with chili powder, cumin, pepper, garilic powder and paprika (as suggested by another reviewer).
i also doubled the sauce as per others suggestions. but it turned out to be a bit too much for our liking. we would actually prefer not having any sauce on top at all, the sauce makes the tortillas soggy and we liked the ends that were more "crisp". so if i make this again i won't double the sauce and just put all the sauce in with the chicken and sprinkle the tops of the tortillas with some of the cheese. but that's just my preference.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe twice this week because it was so good.  The first time, I bought a piece of grilled chicken breast at the prepared foods counter at my local grocer, and it was super easy.  Today, I just grilled up some chicken breast that I had in the freezer and although it required one more pan, it was still a relatively quick and easy meal with a fabulous result.  The store was out of diced green chiles in a can so I bought a couple of fresh jalapeno peppers and used those.  Also, DH thought it would be a great idea to get habanero cheddar instead of regular cheddar so they were scorchingly spicy.  I bought an organic, relatively healthy cream of mushroom soup and used this instead of the Campbell's standby and it made a big difference.  Overall this is a great recipe and I will certainly be adding this into my regular rotation.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
Awesome recipe!  My husband even said it was good and he is a total beef man!  I am replacing my old chicken enchilada recipe with this one!  However, I only had enough of the mixture to fill five tortillas...enough for my husband and I but definitely not enough for 6 servings as shown.  I used a can of cream of chicken and mushroom soup in place of the cream of mushroom.  Perfect!  I made this recipe again and used half of the sauce to mix with the chicken for the filling and poured the other half over the top.  It made six and worked out better.

I love these Chicken Enchiladas, They are my new favorite. The preparation is so easy! It’s unbelievably easy. I did however add my own touches to it; I use diced green bell peppers to substitute the green chiles. And I use Cream of Chicken to substitute the Cream of Mushroom. I also double up on the chicken. 
My husband loved them so much. I now use “Chicken Enchiladas” as my negotiating/bargaining tool to get what I want!

Oh my goodness, was this wonderful!  I've always made enchiladas with ground beef and taco seasoning, and this was such a great change, very easy to make and so so good!  I used about 1/2 of a rotisserie chicken from the store and shredded it and used a can of Rotel.  And I ended up putting 3/4 of the sauce INTO the enchiladas and 1/4 for the outside.  I used the other 1/2 of the chicken in my Zattaran's jumbalaya rice mix.  Perfect dinner. No complaints whatsoever!  Thanks!

text:
Even my arch-conservative nine year old liked this one.
I poached and hand-shredded two large chicken breast fillets, used fresh chilli and garlic and threw in a little cilantro (since I was chopping some anyway for salsa on the side). I also used I can each of cream of chicken and mushroom soups (you really do need the extra sauce). The result was really yummy and, surprisingly, didn't have a "canned soup" taste.

text:
I made these enchiladas last night. I made some changes after reading some of the other reviews. I used 8" tortillas and I used Campbell's Chicken Verde Soup instead of Cream of Mushroom. I also used two bought rotiserie chickens shredded up instead of cooking my own chicken. It was a lot easier and the chicken was so much juicier. I doubled up on the ingredients because I wanted to make a lot. I made 14 enciladas and still had meat left over for tacos the next day. Everyone loved them including daughter. These are now on my list of monthly meals to make. ENJOY!!! Simple and delicious!

text:
This was a very good recipe and I got no complaints from guests.  But personally, I agree with another reviewer.  It was very rich and a little bland.  The richness would be okay if it had a little more flavor that you'd expect from an enchilada dish.  I dashed some chili powder over mine which was a great improvement.  I definately suggest spunking this up with a little taco seasoning or chili powder.  I served this with peas & rice I seasoned with a chicken bullion granules and spicy black bean dip.

text:
Since there was only my daughter and I and she's only 2 I used 2 chicken breasts to make this dish.  I didn't want too many leftovers because i didn't think this would keep real well.
I used the full can of soup and made the sauce the way the recipe called for.  The only thing I did was cut back on the chilis a bit so my daughter would actually eat it.  It was actually quite a good recipe.  I think next time I'd use fresh garlic sauteed with the onion and more cheese.  I didn't find it was cheesy enough as is.  Even so I gave it 5 stars because it has a good flavour and is pretty easy.  Its even easier if you don't have to make the chicken first.  BTW...I fried the chicken with some homemade taco seasoning.  I liked the fact the chicken had some extra flavour to it.

text:
This was excellent!  I was afraid my family wouldn't like it because they are used to red, tomato-based sauce on  their enchiladas, but they loved this!  I made the following changes:  Only used 1/4 cup minced green onion.  Used 98% fat free soup and fat free sour cream.  Added 1/2 tsp chicken fajita seasoning.  Also added 8 minced chilipiquin peppers that grow in my yard instead of green chilies.  Used nine 6" tortillas.  Topped with cheddar and monterey jack cheese.  Used foil to keep tort edges from getting crunchy about halfway through baking time.  Thanks for a new favorite to add to our menu!!!!

I think it's a 3 star, but hubby stated it was a 5 star, so I gave it 4. It was ok.  I added salsa in the sauce...used flour AND corn tortillas to see which was better.  They both tasted the same to me.  I added enchilada red sauce and black beans on top.  I also followed the advice of others and used a rotisserie chicken from the local Walmart (which is actually cheaper than buying uncooked chicken breasts these days!) I mean, the stuff was ok, but not great. Like others have said, don't expect much Mexican taste to this dish.  There are tons of better Mexican recipes. I'll likely stick with those. Sorry! Ally

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used suggestions from other reviews: 1 can cream of chicken, 1 can cream of mushroom, 1 C. sour cream, 4 C. chicken, 1 tsp. cumin, 1/2 tsp. canynne, substitued 1/2 C. enchilada sauce for 1/2 cup milk (after setting aside filling portion), doubled the cheese.  We ate it all up, but most of us added green or red tabasco at the table to punch up the flavor.  Can't really call this enchiladas, or even a Mexican dish.  But as a flour tortilla casserole it just a little too rich and gummy for us.  Would eat it again if someone else made it but I'll probably put my own efforts elsewhere.  I'm still searching for a great chicken enchilada recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
These were great!  I didn't change too much, except to skip the garlic powder and instead add 4-5 cloves garlic and cilantro & lime juice.  I didn't have green chilis so I added so jalopenos instead, which gave it some kick but it wasn't too spicy. I agree that more chicken and cheese was needed so I added that too. I also forgot to add the milk at the end but it was still great.  This recipe made 4 10" tortillas for me, and they weren't overstuffed.  I'm not sure how this recipe could stretch to more than that without doubling or tripling it.  But this amount was perfect for my hubby and I, with leftovers for lunch.  I served these with the red enchilada sauce from this site and I think that really made these something special.  A very easy and delicious recipe.

text:
This was great.  My dh who lived in Mexico said they tasted like the ones his Mexican maid used to fix.  I took the advice of others and doubled the sour cream, added one can of cream of mushroom and one can of cream of chicken soup, and I added extra cheese.  I also doubled the meat.  I added 1 tsp chili powder and 1 tsp garlic powder.  It was awesome.  Oh, this easily filled 7 8-inch tortillas, but no more (and that was because I only mixed 1/4 of the sauce with milk).

text:
Well, personally, I really enjoyed this dish!  I did not get the same response from my husband.  I was really surprised at that.  He had an "issue" with there being Cream of Mushroom soup in an enchilada recipe.  I thought it was great!  My 11 and 5 year olds both ate it without question, but neither exclaimed how much they enjoyed it.  So, I'm mystified.  If were to make it again, I'd probably use Cream of Chicken rather than mushroom, as even I think it might compliment the dish a little better.  I did use Campbells 98% fat free soup, low fat cheddar, and 1% milk.  I don't think these substitutions took anything away from the recipe though, and I felt better about serving this up to the family.  I didn't have green onions on hand, so I used diced sweet onions.  I sprinkled sliced olives over the top before baking, and sprinkled a small amount of Wildtree Herbs' Taco Seasoning over all for a more authentic "Cinco de Mayo" flavor. My son loved adding more low fat Sour Cream atop his.  I'd recommend this recipe.

UPDATE (2/2/05)...Made this again exactly as above, and apparently my husband didn't remember having it before (this time I didn't mention anything about the cream of mushroom soup being in the mix), and my husband commented on how good this was!??!  Again, both kids ate it without comment. I loved it!

text:
Very good, with a couple of minor modifications.  My husband and I like a little "zip" in our enchiladas, so I added 1 tb dried parsley, 1/2 tsp dried oregano, 1/2 tsp ground black pepper, 1 tsp chile powder, and 3 small ground super chile peppers.  Probably any type of ground chile would work, chipotles would be especially nice.  I also used fat free sour cream, you'll never be able to tell the difference with all the other ingrediants.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
Wow!  This was delicious.  I have made enchiladas before and was disappointed, but these were phenominal and my husband LOVED them.  I made a few changes; I didn't have sour cream, chilies, or garlic powder (imagine!) so I left them out and it was fine.  I also found the filling to be too little for 6, so I made 5 enchiladas.  I sautéed some chicken strips with spices (chili powder, Mrs. Dash!) and also added extra seasoning to the sauce.  I baked the enchiladas for about 25 minutes and they were not soggy at all.  Great meal with a green salad.  Yum!

text:
I really enjoyed this as well.  I made a few changed, combining changes suggested by other reviewers.  I also doubled the recipie, and it was perfect for 10 little tortillas.  I cooked fresh chicken in Taco seasoning, I used 1 can of cream of mushroom soup and a little over 1 cup of chicken brother instead of doubling on the cream soup.  I used salsa instead of milk for the sauce to put on top, and instead of regular chedder cheese, I used store bought "tex-mex" variety.  My family adored these...and they are a pretty tough crowd.  All my changes made it pretty spicy which is perfect for me.

I added a can of creamed chicken with herbs and some cumin and cayanne.  I also used corn tortillas instead of flour - but how do you keep them from ripping? text:
I used chicken breast cut into strips and cooked them using Fajita spice to add flavor to the chicken.
Instead of rolling the enchiladas I cut the tortillas into strips and covered the bottom of a greased cassarole dish. I added the mix topped with more tortilla strips then added the remaining sauce and cheese.

I also tried using the frozen Tyson chicken fajita strips but they were no where near as good as using your own chicken and fajita seasoning.

text:
I have made this twice now and we love it! This last time I used corn tortillas. Just put them in the microwave wrapped in dampened paper towels just long enough to heat and soften them. Then add the chicken mixture and roll up the same way as the flour tortillas. I am use to corn for enchiladas and flour for burritos. Works wonderfully. Even though you are using green chiles this recipe is not too spicy for anyone. Thanks

Display Name:
GENUINEGIN
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made serious adaptations to this recipe because I didn't want to want for a trip to the store!!.  I was trying to use some leftover grilled chicken (mine was marinated in Adolphs for the Grill Garlic) so I found this recipe which called for garlic.  I omitted the garlic, since my chicken was garlic.  I used Cream of Chicken Soup. In addition to the ingredients listed I used 3 tablespoons red pepper and sauted it with the green onions.  I used "marble cheddar" I'm sorry I'm unsure of exactly what that is, but it's cheddar yellow and white marble.I used a bit more sour cream and cheese(simply because we like it) and about 1/3 to 1/2 cup milk to get what I considered to be the optimal consistency. I combined all the ingredients except the sour cream in a microwave dish and heated until bubbly. Then I stirred in the sour cream. I buttered the bottom of a large square micro dish, heated the tortillas, laid them on the buttered bottom and filled and rolled (an old trick I picked up in Mexico)  I only used 4 because they were so large and filled the dish.  I had just enough "filling" left over to wet the tops of the tortillas, then I completely covered them with the shredded marbled cheddar cheese.  I put the lid on, stuck it in the microwave and cooked on high for 6 minutes.  The result? Heaven!!  Thank you so much for sharing your recipe

country:
None
text:
My husband and I LOVED this.  I took the advice from other reviewers and substituted cream of chicken soup
for the cream of mushroom.  Also, be sure to use a *sharp* cheddar cheese (Cracker Barrel 
makes a good one) which I think adds a lot of flavor.  Aside from that, I didn't think it needed any other 
spices, and I love highly-seasoned dishes.  If you're expecting a traditional red-sauce/corn 
tortilla enchildada, you will be disappointed.  But if you're a fan of creamy sauces
you should really enjoy this.  We will definitely make it again soon.

My husband hates onions and peppers, however he really liked this dish.  I did make a few revisions: I used minced onion in place of the green onions and I pureed the green chilies so there wasn't large pieces in the sauce.  I also added chili powder, garlic salt, paprika and a little poulty seasoning otherwise I think it would be to bland.  I used 2 cups of cheese instead of 1 cup and I put an additional 1/2 cup chopped chicken on top of the enchiladas.  Will make again. Thanks

text:
This is a wonderful recipe!  I took the advice of others and made a few changes:  substituted cream of chicken soup for cream of mushroom, added a few jalapenos peppers (used Ortega sliced jalapenos and diced them), added 1/8 tsp. of Cumin, added 1/4 cup extra of sour cream to the mix.  I topped the final product with a bit of sour cream and some black olives, and served with Cheesy Mexican rice.  My family loved.  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe and for all of the great advice!

text:
Made this as a "low cal" version (with low fat and low cal ingredients) with leftover roast chicken and it was absolutetly delicious!  My 12 month old even liked it!  To decrease the amount of cal/serving even more, I added 1/2 pound chopped mushrooms (in food processor) to the chicken, put the mixture in 8 6" tortillas (making 8 instead of 6 servings).  Baked it on the BBQ at minimum for 25 minutes.  This was the second time we made this, and it is now part of our recipe rotations!  I'm on weight watchers, and one serving is equivalent to 5 points, just for your info!

text:
Quite good and would definitely make again. Only mods were:

* Used ~3/4 cup green onion (3 green onions)
* Used shredded chicken from Instant pot (1.2 pounds - ~2 cups)
* Used small corn tortillas (6 inch) and yielded 13 enchiladas

Thoughts on future mods would be to sub the can of green chiles with fresh chopped jalapeno and/or red/green peppers.

Im just really confused on the number of ratings ranking this dish so highly. I do not like leaving a bad review, but good or bad it can maybe give others insight. When I started making this I was feeling proud that I was preparing a new well reviewed meal for my family, even the “sauce” seemed to be creamy and a delicious starting point...however when it came down to the filling there was not enough to properly fill the tortillas. The sauce was super salty and tasted very canned and you might as well eat cream of mushroom straight from the can that’s your thing or dip a warm tortilla in a can of cream of mushroom and eat it that way. I cook prep-heavy meals almost every day and am big into cooking. This was terrible and I will not be making it again.

text:
Great recipe.  I made only a couple small changes. I used corn tortillas instead of flour. I cut up two large chicken breasts into small pieces, seasoned them with salt,  garlic and cayenne pepper and fried them in the pan with a bit of olive oil. Then put the chicken aside, drained the oil and added the butter. I used less green chilles than called for because I just didn't care for the taste. The rest of the recipe I followed however,  and they turned out great. My family ate the entire dish!! Including my very PICKY 7 year old who loved it. And my 6 year old said, "I wish this was the only food there was in the whole world."

city:

text:
First time making and I don't make Chicken  Enchiladas  but read the reviews and decided to do this one as it was quite a simple recipe. I had flour tortillas and wanted to use some of them up and try them in this. I lightly toasted the tortillas in a cast iron pan first then added the mixture before rolling up. I used 5 12 inch ones. I added about 1/4c of yellow pepper and 1/4 cup of green pepper and used diced yellow onion rather than green. I sauted all that in the butter first. Did everything else the same but I guess I added more garlic to taste used 11/2 cup of rottisare chicken and I added a 1/2 tsp paprika. these turned out yummy! Served with a spinach salad that had avocaodo and dried cranberries and silvers of pepper with a balsamic dressing. Would make these again!  My man ate 2 and I ate one so we have 2 leftover for lunches.

text:
This is an excellent recipe.  I always double the ingredients to make 12 total -- my hungry family of 5 needs at least 2 enchiladas each. The first time, I made the recipe exactly as written except I used salsa verde instead of chiles. Came out wonderfully. The second and subsequent times, I used a nacho/taco blend shredded cheese instead of just plain cheddar. Since I can get it prepackaged, why not? I also smeared a little refried beans across the tortilla first before the filling.  This is a very adaptable recipe and nice to have in my favorites folder.

Display Name:
KJD

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is DELICIOUS!  Only difference I made is with how I prepared the chicken. I have no patience with cutting up the chicken. Upon purchasing boneless chicken breast, I asked the meat department to “cube” the chicken on their meat grinder (similar to cubes steaks). The meat department sliced the chicken breast in half and cubed it running it through their meat grinder 2 or 3 times.  From there, I followed the recipe. I simmered the grind chicken as a whole after it boiled, as instructed. Then placed it in the skillet after the onions mixed with butter caramelized, and cut it up with a good spatula directly in the pan.  As I added the rest of the ingredients it called for, I continued cutting up the chicken til it looked shredded as it simmered. Viola!  It worked great, and the chicken was so juicy and tender!  I continued to follow the rest of the recipe exactly as written. This is a KEEPER!  Thank you for making this recipe available on AllRecipes!

Rating:
5

I love this recipe! I leave out the green onions (kids don’t like) and substituted cream of chicken for the cream of mushroom (husband hates mushrooms). This has become a family favorite. This certainly isn’t traditional enchiladas- but, perfect burrito casserole.

text:
Was easy to make and came out very good. I would only change or add a couple of things. 
1- add some other seasonings for more flavor, I added a little salt, pepper, and some cumin.
2- I would put a slight amount of the sauce in the baking pan after it is sprayed. Without some sauce on the bottom the tortilla gets a little hard.

But again, very easy to make.

This is a great recipe.  Different from the same old beef enchiladas I usually make at home. I couldn’t find the larger corn tortillas so ended up using the small ones-yielded 10 total.  Highly recommend this recipe and I will definitely be on our family repeat list.

text:
This dish turned out to be really tasty! I only had Monterey Jack cheese so that’s that I used. Next time I make this, I think I’ll use Pepper Jack cheese. I tasted the chicken mixture before assembling the enchiladas and found it to be way too mild for our taste so I jazzed it up with couple of dashes of Cayenne Pepper.  This was the “missing ingredient” that made a world of difference.  I also added it to the sauce for the topping.  This recipe is definitely a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making  enchiladas,  and I didn't want a recipe with red sauce.  I used a hybrid flour corn 8 inch tortillas. I brushed each tortilla with olive oil and then fried each one for a minute or so, to soften the tortilla and prevent it from cracking when rolling. I also used a mix of cheddar and jack cheese. I poached and shredded the chicken. And finally (if you are still reading) I used a mix of jalapeno and red chilli peppers. 
They were awesome.. I will definitely make these again and wouldn't change a thing.

country:
None
text:
i started w/ 3 raw boneless skinless chick breasts & used lots of spices to cook 7 min on low boil & 7 min resting in the hot broth.  i cut up the chick before poaching for ease of use. since we don't eat salt do to high B/P i use gobs of herbs & spices & i used cream of mushroom soup w/ roasted garlic. i only got 4 enchiladas using 8" tortillas out of the recipe & i used low sodium chili w/out beans on 1/3 of the enchiladas prior to baking. we have decided this is one of the best meals i've ever made!  i highly recommend! i also managed to cook the whold thing from start to finish in one stove pan & 1 glass casserole dish so easy clean up!

I loved it...although, I didn't have the right ingredients so I loved the "idea of it!" I only had 4 tortillas, no sour cream and no green chilies. I poured in Salsa Verde instead and skipped the sour cream. Of course, the enchiladas were rather soupy with too much sauce, but the flavor was definitely worth it and I'll try it again with the correct ingredients. I will probably always leave out the sour cream because I didn't miss it or the calories it would have added.

text:
These chicken enchiladas were pretty tasty (with seasoned meat). I used corn tortillas instead (because enchiladas are normally made with corn) but that’s where I messed up. I should’ve used flour OR I should have First figured out how to stop them from cracking once rolled...the end result wasn’t as neat as I would have liked them to be but that didn’t compromise the taste at all....oh I also doubled the recipe to have enough for my family....found that doubling the sauce was absolutely unnecessary....the suggested amount would have been enough even for a double serving....overall, this one is a winner and I will use it again.

With 12 inch tortillas the chicken mix sauce was too little, barely enough for 5 tortillas, and using a 13 by 9 glass baking dish was a little skimpy. I eyeballed the pan and decided to add some green enchilada sauce on hand to fill it a bit more and topped with a 4 cheese Mexican shred mix and this salvaged it. The finished product was o.k. but could have also used some salt and pepper in the mix to season it a bit better.

Display Name:
Martha Keever Seagle

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4327557.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is good basic recipe.  I was skeptical about using the cream of mushroom soup, but it works!
I know the tortilla police are out there, but my family actually prefers the flour tortillas, so that is what I used.  Yes, I know that authentic enchiladas use corn tortillas.

The base recipe needs more spice for our tastes.  I used a 7 oz can of green chiles, added 1/2 tsp of cayenne pepper, and 1/2 tsp of cumin.  Still could have used more.  I also increased the amount of cheese for the filling and for the topping---added some cilantro and a few sliced jalapenos on top so that anyone who doesn't like them could pick them off.  I will definitely make these again and I appreciate the base recipe very much!

text:
Have to agree with WoodAngela. Enchiladas are made with CORN tortillas...... Not flour. I live in Arizona. Can't get much closer to Mexico where the authentic enchiladas are made with corn tortillas. A flour tortilla makes it a burrito, which is fine, just call it a burrito. Try this with CORN tortillas and see what you think

Made and reviewed EXACTLY as written. ( Please do not rate a recipe based on your revisions.!!)   I found this very bland and not typical Mexican flavor.  You could add anything to suite your taste; con, black beans, diced tomatoes, cilantro, etc. 
I would personally prefer a corn shell (it is an enchilada after all), less cream texture especially in filling.  A thinner , cilantro based cream sauce for the top would be nice.

text:
Perfect!  Made it as written and one of my kids favorite meals.  I make this about weekly.  When I’m in a hurry I used a sour cream based onion dip in place of the sour cream and cooking the onions in butter.  I also slow cook the chicken so it’s ready when I get home from work to throw together and bake.  My family also likes black beans so I throw a can of rinsed black beans in there sometimes also.  Colby jack cheese also goes well with the dish if you’re out of cheddar.

Display Name:
boxiebabe
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will answer the first 2 questions in this box first.  It says "Did you make any changes?".  Yes.  "Will you make it again?".  Absolutely!
 I am rating this 5 stars with the small changes I made to the original recipe.  Firstly, I used corn tortillas that I had VERY lightly fried in veggie oil then drained on paper towels.  There were enough innards to make 9 enchiladas (I used 2 chicken breasts and it came out to 2 cups - shredded) -  rather than the 1.5 the recipe called for).  To the innards, I made the following changes:  I added about 1 1/2 Tbsp taco seasoning to the mixture.  I added 1 small can of sliced black olives.  For the sauce that you dump on at the end, I only added about 1/3 of cup of milk, not a 1/4.  Lastly, I used Campbell's Cream of Chicken with herbs that I grabbed by mistake instead of mushroom soup.  I used more cheese on top than it called for. 
After all is said and done, I didn't follow the original recipe to the T, but with the changes I made it was EXCELLENT!  It will definitely be added to our regular line up.  I didn't want to fill up with side dishes so I just opened a can of corn for the side.  They're SO good that you won't want a bunch of other stuff on the side.  Save room for this delicious dish.  
PS.  Some reviewers said it was dry and they'd recommend doubling the sauce portion.  I didn't think they were dry at all and I only used one serving of sauce on 9 corn enchiladas.  Maybe it's because I used corn torts and fried them a tiny bit

country:

text:
The kids loved it even thought I screwed it up a bit.  I forgot to split the sauce before adding the chicken so I just made more tortilla's. After baking I added cheese on the top and put it back in the oven for 5 minutes to melt.   I also made a few changes to the sauce based on what I had on hand and what other reviewers said. I doubled the sauce and used extra chicken too.  I used one large regular onion.   I added about 2 TBS lime juice and a bunch of shakes of oregano to the sauce at the end. I also only had one can of green chili's so I opened a can of rotel and took all the chili's out as well as a few tomato's. The kids didn't even notice the tomato's. When I ask the kids to rate my meals, I often get a 7. This one got an 8 and 9 which is AWESOME.

userID:
886179
Display Name:
BOOKIE 
isPro:
False
followersCount:
72
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
554
favoritesCount:
6781
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
12 16 16  .... http://allrecipes.com/recipe/8694/chicken-enchiladas-ii/  ....  I had 3c chix to use (doubled the recipe) & was hoping this would be a hit  - meaning leftovers would be eaten.  Done!  :D  An almost Christmas miracle happened "I like this" from E, 19.  Wow!  I changed just a  bit, but not enough to influence the base recipe.  'Subbed 1c diced onion with 3-4cl garlic;  8oz green chiles (undrained); cream of mushroom & cream of chicken, 1c sour cream; added 2T taco sauce.  Removed 3c sauce for topping.  To remaining in pan, added 3c chix & 1 1/2c Mexican cheese blend.  To a can of refried beans, added 2T taco sauce.  Spread about 2T bean mixture in each of 12 (10"?) flour tortillas, then chix mixture.  Put a little of the sauce in the oiled dish, then rolled tortillas.  It was snug in a 9x13.  'Thought there was too much sauce before baking, but not after.  :D  Topped with the sauce then 1 1/2c  Mexican cheese blend.  Baked uncovered till bubbly.  This is mild, as most Mexican food is , until you add spicy ingredients.  Jalapenos, black olives, tomatoes, etc  on top would be good.  Sprinkled lightly with Cajun seasoning for flavor & paprika & a little parsley for color.  :)  Thumbs up!

Love this recipe. Made it a few times already and it always goes over well. I made a couple changes for convenience. I have used regular onions instead of green because I was out and it worked fine. Plus I usually use canned tomatoes with green chilies instead of just chilies because that's what I normally have on hand. Both work great. I also go heavy on the sour cream and a little extra milk so I can stretch the sauce to make more filling. Overall this recipe is EXCELLENT

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As other reviewers suggested, I added 1/4 teaspoon cumin, 1/4 teaspoon cayenne powder, 1/4 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon black pepper, 1 tablespoon chili powder and 1/2 cup of salsa.  To kick up the spice, I added half a can of jalapeno and half a can of green chilies.  I also added a can of black beans (rinsed and drained) with the chicken.  It was medium spicy with all these ingredients (I had to get an extra glass of water!), but very tasty and delicious.

userID:
17887120
Display Name:
Tiffany Swain
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3484207.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made enchiladas of any kind before (and okay, if I'm being honest...I've never even eaten enchiladas before).  But this looked good.  I wanted to try it, but I'm a very picky eater...so yes, I made a few changes and made it my way.  I did use this as a base though and I loved it!  My husband loved it too!

The first thing I changed was that I left out onion (both my husband and I hate onion).  Next, instead of putting green chiles in, I diced up green, red, and jalapeño peppers because that is what I had on hand.  I melted the butter, added the garlic powder and then tired in the peppers.

Instead of cream of mushroom, I used cream of chicken.  I'm not a huge mushroom fan myself and so we usually only keep stock of cream of chicken.

I also forgot to add milk to the mix before I spread it on top...so I just dumped a bit of milk over the top before adding cheese.

The biggest thing I did different was to add a lot of cumin.  Cumin is the basis of taco seasoning, so I thought it would be a good idea.  I didn't have any leftover chicken, so I cooked some up tonight and I seasoned them with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and cumin.  Then I also added cumin into the sauce.

We'll definitely make it again.

text:
My husband's favorite but there isn't a lot of filling. It's not my favorite tortilla to filling ratio.  So, when I'm making the filling, I add random stuff - colorful bell peppers, black beans, rice, etc. More filling = more flavor needed so I add another can of green chilis.  Great cheat to make adding extra stuff easier - use 90 second rice (I use 2 pouches) so you can nuke it and toss it in without making more dishes.

Overall a good recipe.  I agree that this is more of a wet burrito than an enchilada.  I always have to double the recipe to have enough for my family - and find it works perfectly.  A little on the dryer side, try to make a smidge more sauce is you want it more of an enchilada consistency.

text:
This was a simple green chile chicken enchilada recipe that is relatively mild but still delicious.  It was just what I was looking for.  I have only minor complaints.  First, this does not serve 6, unless you mean six little ones or you have a lot of side dishes.  I doubled the recipe for my family of 7, and even at 12 servings, it was sadly not enough for teenagers.   Also, the tortillas are very lightly stuffed and I prefer much more chicken in the middle of mine so it doesn't seem like just tortilla and sauce.  With a few modifications, it will likely be a family favorite!

text:
We've never had enchiladas before, and we both enjoyed this dish immensely! I followed the recipe except I used Monterey Jack cheese because I didn't have cheddar, and I only had the smaller 8-inch tortillas on hand. I managed to fill eight of them and had plenty of sauce as written. I do like the idea of jazzing it up with taco seasoning or refried beans as other reviewers have suggested, but we liked it just as it was. It was very easy to put together. Thanks for the recipe and the inspiration for our first introduction to enchiladas!

text:
I really like like this recipes as is. The flavors were pretty good and my only annoyance was that in the given recipe I don't feel it allowed nearly enough filling or sauce, so plan on doubling this. I have read many of the other reviews and to be honest if I wanted an authentic real Mexican chicken enchilada I would go out and eat at an authentic restaurant and get one there. I think this is simple, quick and easy for a fast meal at home. Obviously if you have a lot more time you could add a whole lot to this recipe and make a whole bunch of substitutions, but as a mom I just don't have the time. It is a great base recipe and my family enjoyed it immensely.

text:
This was a really easy and fast recipe to follow! Because I live in an area where some ingredients are harder to come by I changed the recipe a bit but still got great results. I used plain yogurt instead of sour cream, powdered mushroom soup mix (cooked with less water to keep the soup thick) instead of condensed mushroom soup, and shredded mozzarella cheese instead of cheddar. I found that the soup and yogurt sauce was a little more watery, but that really didn't bother me or sacrifice flavor.The sauce soaked in right the tortilla shell really well in the oven. I added the rest of my cheese in the last 5 minutes of baking as I found it only took about 15 minutes to cook.

Display Name:
Bambam

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/952630.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me try this again. My initial review was edited and not by me.  I have made these enchiladas several times and only recently reviewed it. This recipe uses a can of condensed soup.  If you are like me, you avoid using the gloopy-gloppy cans of condensed soup. It is very easy to make your own cream soup base and it takes less than 5 minutes.  You can find a recipe for "cream soup base" on this site and several on other sites. It really is worth the few extra minutes and is so simple and a good sub for any recipe that calls for a can of condensed soup. This enchilada recipe goes together easily and is very tasty. It has a good, chewy consistency with pleasant flavors. The flour tortillas reminded me a bit of "dumplings".  I have seen recipes for chicken-n-dumplings where torn-up flour tortillas are added to the chicken stock. Maybe that's what this reminds me of. The green chili's are subtle, and do not make this dish spicy at all. If you're looking for spicy, you may want to add hot peppers or pepper flakes. I think you could easily adapt or add flavors you and your family likes. Thanks for submitting. This is a keeper!
Review:

5

text:
We love this recipe, and have been making it for years!  Along the way I’ve made a few tweaks that are even more yummy:

I use cream of ONION soup, not it’s not overly onion flavored.
I add 1/2 cup water to the sauce BEFORE dividing, and no milk at the end
I double the garlic powder, and add 1 1/2 tsp cumin
I use 2 1/4 cups chicken
I use Monteray Jack cheese instead of cheddar.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe as written but substituted ingredients to make it gluten free for my kid with celiac. I used GF cream of mushroom soup and corn tortillas. I left the pan of enchiladas cooking in the oven with instructions for my teenage son to pull out when ready, and I headed out to a meeting. I returned to an empty casserole dish. Not a crumb left! This recipe got rave reviews and will be enjoyed again in our house. I think it's easy enough to teach my teenagers to prepare too. Regarding the corn tortillas, there is no need to fry them in oil. Just pop a couple at a time in to the microwave for 20 - 30 seconds to warm them. Then quickly fill each tortilla before they cool. Super easy and scrumptious!

text:
Love the spicy creaminess. How can you go wrong, eh. Next time I'll use fire roasted chiles and more chili powder to spice it up Southwestern style. In addition to sliced black olives, I'll add a bit of fresh corn. I also made half with flour and half with corn tortillas. Heat them with olive oil spray in a medium hot pan so they roll easily. Enchiladas are all about the cheeses you use and the spices in the sauce.

text:
Delicious!  I substituted cream of chicken soup for the mushroom soup and omitted the butter and green onions.  I also added a little bit of ground cumin to the mix.  Instead of using the mixture to coat the pan, I greased my glass baking dish with a thin coating of vegetable oil so I could use most of the mix inside the enchiladas and put a thin coating on top.  I covered the pan with aluminum foil while it baked and served it with salsa and sour cream.  Can't wait to make them again!

Display Name:
AnneL

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe! I made a few changes, first by ignoring the call for pre-cooked, cubed chicken (ew) and instead making my own pan-fried (no breading) chicken breasts. They were marinated southwest style. After cooking them I chopped them into small, thin pieces. I the immediately made the sauce, ignoring the call for onions and using Cream of Chicken soup instead. Instead of adding the cheese to the chicken, I added it right into the sauce to let it melt. I also used salt, garlic salt, black pepper, and hot sauce to give the sauce more dimension. I mixed 1/4 of the sauce with my chicken, loaded and rolled my enchiladas, smothered them with the rest of the sauce and cheese, and baked until the sauce bubbled. It was a huge success! Would definitely make this again, tweaking the recipe further to change it up. Delicious and simple!

text:
This is REALLY bland. I exchanged the cream of mushroom sauce for cream of chicken.  Then, I seasoned the sauce/chicken mixture with a ton of Southwest flavor Mrs. Dash, Tabasco sauce, and a little salt and pepper to taste.  The extra spices (mainly the Mrs. Dash) made all the difference.  In fact, with my changes this was REALLY good; creamy and spicy.  I will keep the recipe only because of my changes.  However, I don't think I should have to do all the extra work for a recipe that rates this high.  Very disappointing.

text:
This recipe doesn't have the wow factor, but it isn't bad either. It's a quick weekday meal that everyone can fill up on and enjoy. No hot spicy flavors here, which is good for families with younger children who prefer more mild tastes. I used whole wheat flour tortillas and spread a little sauce on the bottom of the pan to keep the tortillas from drying out and toughening up during baking. A good basic recipe to add variety to the weekly dinner menu.

imapkru

city:
