country:
None
text:
I found the basics for this recipe to be a good start.  I agree with previous comments that it is a little bland.  I made the following changes which worked out very nice.  I will make this again and again.  I stuck with the flour tortillas for this recipe.
4-5 Chicken breast coated in Taco Seasoning and cooked till done in olive oil and garlic; then shredded.  I did not add sauce to the chicken while cooking.
Sauce:
1 can cream of chicken and mushroom soup (this is a combo can).  
2/3 cup sour cream
1/3 cup milk
7 oz chopped green chilies
2 tbsp Taco Seasoning
1 tsp Cumin
1 tsp Chili Powder
1 tbsp Cilantro
Use 2 heaping tbsp of sauce per enchilada
Add additional milk to remaining sauce before pouring over chicken.
Use whatever cheese you like.  I used a Mexican blend and added it as layer when filling the enchiladas instead of putting it in the sauce.
This makes 6 large (burritos), lol... er enchiladas.
Cook at 350 for 35-40 min.  Suggest to top with cheese last 15 min.
Next time I might try to incorporate some cream cheese into this in place of the sour cream, or use both.

I am not a Latina, and don't hold to the "you have to use this kind of tortilla" school.  I absolutely admire anyone who argues for ethnic correctness. I did follow the advice of others and do one can of cr. of mush, and one cr. of chix.  Delightful.  I am a sauce person, and this worked for me.  Oh, I also used rotissierie chix- good comment there.  Better than I could have made it.  Thank you.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is the second time I have made these.  Learning from the first time around, instead of canned cream of mushroom soup, which contains MSG (most of them anyway), I found a recipe on this site for "Cream Soup Base," then halved it for the correct amount, and used that instead.  I also added sliced black olives, used brown onion instead of green (for more flavor), used shredded chicken instead of cubed (from a $4.00 rotisserie chicken at Costco - what a deal and how convenient!), and added a small can of green enchilada sauce in place of the milk (because I thought the original recipe was a bit bland) and coated the bottom of the pan with a layer of sauce (so the tortillas didn't come out dry).  I plan to make it a third time, however, and I am going to add cumin and maybe some cayanne to the "Cream Soup Base" and double the chicken mixture (it just didn't seem like enough filling).  Also, I may try corn tortillas, as others have suggested. So... the original recipe gets a "3," my second attempt gets a "4," and I'm hoping my third will be a "fiver." We'll see!

text:
Very quick and easy and delicious. I didn't have green onions so used a quarter cup of chopped regular onions. I also added half a package of drained frozen spinach and a handful of canned corn, to use up leftovers. I also added a chopped jalopeno pepper to add some spice. Instead of setting aside 3/4 of the sauce, I set aside half to avoid a dry filling because of the added veggies. No matter what you add to it, it is a great base for enchiladas.

userID:
3824854
Display Name:
slugger
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe.  I made it for a gathering, and there was nothing left.  The only reason I didn't give it five stars was the fact that I made some changes and to me, a perfect five-star rating means it doesn't require changes.  These were personal preferences, and others may feel they're not needed.  To me, how the chicken is cooked is as important as anything else.   I oven-roasted the chicken, rubbed with vegetable oil, salted (both sides), pepper, ground Bay seasoning, garlic powder, three splashes of liquid smoke, topped with ten thin pats of butter (quadrupled recipe).  Cover. Oven 325 1.5 hours.  I adapted this to my taste first by following others' suggestions to use cream of chicken soup, only that's the only kind I used...no cream of mushroom.  Since I quadrupled the recipe, I halved the amount of green chilies, and then oven-roasted four poblano peppers rubbed with vegetable oil on 300 for an hour-and-a-half, cut off the tops, removed the seeds and skin, then blended them to a puree with an immersion blender.  From that puree, I took about four tablespoons and added it to the soup mixture in the pan.   Since the poblanos were a tad bitter, I added a tablespoon of sugar to the soup mixture.  Another change:  instead of cheddar, I used Monterrey Jack.  I then followed a reviewer's suggestion to use white corn tortillas and heat them in hot oil. These were a HUGE HIT.  My husband loved them as well.  I'll continue to make this in this way in the future.

text:
Great recipe, however, ENCHILADAS ARE MADE WITH CORN TORTILLAS!!! I swear every recipe I have ever found for enchiladas uses flour tortillas. I don't understand why because enchiladas taste sooo much better with corn tortillas and that is the way they are supposed to be made, no matter what you put in/on them! Corn tortillas are a lot healthier for you then flour tortillas as well.

I agree that corn tortillas are the only way to go.  I have been making a similar recipe for years and simply boil water in a small pot with a small rack over the top, and steam the corn  tortillas prior to filling. They become pliable within seconds. and it saves on fat and calories.

text:
These are by far the best chicken enchilada recipe I have found! The only change that I make is to use yellow corn tortillas as that is what really makes them "enchiladas" and not "burritos".  I have added a can of drained tomatoes and green chilis for a variation.  We serve with homemade spanish rice and black beans.  My entire family raves about this recipe.  I like to buy a roasted chicken from my local grocery store to help impart some flavor, or even use fajita chicken breasts which you cook ahead of time.  Awesome!

I really want to give this recipe more stars.  However I just can't.  I doubled the sauce like other suggested and it was better, however it does not make enough filling to fill all 6 tacos, I could only get 4 and they were not very full, a small line of filling.  Also there is too much sour cream, I will use half next time.  It was too bland, it is a great recipe otherwise and very easy to do.  I am glad that I finally found a good non tomato enchilada recipe that I can change up to make better.  I would definitely make again but I will be changing and adding stuff.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

I used this recipe as a base. I live in a country where I cannot find many canned items, so I had to make them from scratch. This was AMAZING!  I thought the cream soup was a little weird when I read it, but now I'm convinced that restaurants use it in their enchilada sauce. country:
None
text:
This is a good version, but it's definitely not authentic. My husband hates chicken, but LOVES this recipe. Whenever I mention I am making chicken enchiladas, he wants this one. I add low-sodium cream of chicken and cream of mushroom. Instead of green onions, I use green chiles. I don't add milk to my recipe and I usually use leftover chicken to save on time. I recommend this recipe to those who don't like traditional enchilada's...although my personal favorite is the corn tortilla. I also use chili powder on my chicken and in my sauce along with the garlic powder, it's not spicy, but it gives it excellent flavor.

text:
This has become a family favorite! I changed a few things from the original recipe too. I use the Perdue southwestern chicken strips to make it even easier, and add more flavor. And since my husband likes sauce, I doubled the sauce recipe by using 2 cans of cream of mushroom soup and 1 cup of sour cream. I also cover the dish with aluminum foil for the first 15 minutes of baking. I think having more sauce and covering the dish also helps with preventing the ends of the tortillas from becoming dry. YUMMY!

text:
Very good recipe, although it took a bit longer because I didn't have cooked chicken. I sauted fresh sliced mushrooms with the filling and it went well with the topping. I was always skeptical about enchiladas with cream soup in them, but my husband doesn't seem to like any of the red enchilada sauces I've made, and he said these were his favorite enchiladas I've made. I used 1 clove fresh garlic, low fat sour cream, and seasoned the chicken with chili powder and a little cumin and crushed red pepper.

text:
This was a good base recipe as most have said, not "authentic", but a good Americanized version, especially if you like mild, creamy, cheesy enchiladas, which my family does. I doubled the recipe, added extra seasonings as suggested and to taste, used boiled legs, thighs and breast for meat variety, and then added an extra can of crm chicken and milk to stretch the sauce. Adults liked it, could build up the spicy with other toppings, kids liked it because it was mild enough and easy to eat. Served with spanish rice and sweet corn cake  and it was a real hit.

text:
Easy and tasty.  I read several modifications. 1. Added diced pepper(1) and onion(1) 2. Used 'mexican blend' cheese instead and 3. Cooked chicken, onions and peppers with a low sodium taco mix 4. Removed garlic powder 5. I also remembered a trick from America's test kitchen.  Use corn tortillas (I used small ones as I think they are better.  8"?)  Spray both sides lightly with a vegetable spray and bake in oven for 4 minutes in the same tray you use.  No mess and hardly any additional work.  If you are picky, use a baking sheet or foil. 6. When spraying, open the dishwasher and spray your tortillas above it.  Anything that goes over will be cleaned in the next wash.  :)

country:
None
text:
Just to respond to the last reviewer:  This is NOT an authentic Mexican enchilada recipe.  This is an *American-ized* version of a Mexican dish, therefore flour tortillas are perfectly acceptable.  In fact, ALL white chicken enchilada recipes use white cream sauces and flour tortillas...it's not meant to be "authentic."  Authentic recipes use corn tortillas and red or green sauces.  BTW, this is a great recipe!  Wonderful base to add other ingredients too as well!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

text:
I just made this recipe tonight for dinner. It was GREAT! I used a can of cream of chicken as well as a half can of cream of mushroom. It kept the enchiladas very moist. I also boiled my chicken breasts in water and taco seasoning mix before shredding it. I added some of the taco seasoning/water mixture to my enchilada creme sauce to add some more flavor. I also added a whole large white onion and softened them when I cooked 1/2 the amount of green onions. (i hope that makes sense haha) Over all this was an instant hit and will be seen on our dinner table again and again.

userID:
2120147
Display Name:
lynne
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe for sour cream chicken enchiladas.  I do have a hint to share, that I discovered out of desperation when I had everything all mixed and found there were no tortillas in the house.  Rather than wrapping the filling in corn or flour tortillas, put in a hard taco shell.  Line the shells in your pan, fitting in as many as you wish.  Even if they stand straight up, that's fine.  Cover the entire top with the sauce, making sure that all of the crunchy shells have topping on them.  In the course of baking they will soften perfectly, and are much easier to fill that regular corn tortillas.  We vary the recipe by using whatever meat on hand, and substituting cream of chicken for cream of mushroom.  Thanks for a great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
4

Other that that, I followed the reciped pretty close. I sauted the chicken with some taco seasoning.  i also added chille powder and oregano to the sauce.
I also spread some refried beans on the tortillas before I filled them.

Since I do like pretty much everything, I sauted some onion, black olives and peppers in some butter and sprikled them on top of my enchilladas.

My boyfriend was happy, and I was happy.
I got my yucky vegtables, and he got his meat and cheese. 

This will definately be added to the small list of recipes we can both enjoy!
Thank you!

text:
I made these last night and both my boyfriend and I loved them.  I did double the sauce recipe and used 1 can cream of chicken, 1 can mushroom - I think this was a little too much sauce, but I think just 1 can would be too little.  I used regular onion because the store was out of green - tasted great.  And I added a little taco seasoning to the sauce which was really good.  For the chicken, I just shredded one whole rotisserie chicken.  I also used corn tortillas.  They came out great, although a little messy getting them out of the pan - I don't think I let them sit long enough after coming out of the oven.  I'm giving this 5 stars because it was a cheaper, healthier way to make our favorite dish Enchilada Suizas from "On the Border"!!

country:

text:
I was very disappointed in this recipe.  I think it should be much better given the ratings other people have given it.  It should be practically perfect as written and it needs a lot of work.  You do not need 6 12-inch tortillas; I used 5 10-inch tortillas and there wasn't enough filling, as the recipe stands for that - I had to add a can of black beans to increase the filling amount.  The sauce and filling had a taste reminiscent of the condensed soup used which I found unappealing.  I would have rather spent extra time to make a white sauce first.  If you could get over the soup taste, there wasn't much more to taste; very bland.  I used olive oil instead of butter and other than my can of black beans I kept to the recipe.  I'm sure there are better recipes for enchiladas, please try to find one instead of making this.

text:
Not sure how authentic this is but it tastes amazing so oh well!! I prefer to use ground chicken instead of cubed chicken breast, as it gives a more uniform texture, is easier to roll the enchiladas, and faster to prepare. I think someone else suggested using corn tortillas, which I did and feel it gave it a better taste and were maybe easier to work with. I ended up needing two packages of corn tortillas, as this made a lot of filling. Really really good, and easy.

text:
I had to give this a three because the original recipe was good but for my family I would have to change many things before serving it again.  What I mean to say is what the other reviews said, "use as a base and be creative".  For instance, the mushroom soup flavor really dominants so I will use cream of chicken next time.  Also would double the recipe only because we like to have some left over, this only served one enchilada for almost 5 (had to skimp a little on one of the last tortilla fillings).  If made with rice on the side one enchilada should be sufficient per person.  Next time I will try adding black beans, fresh garlic, maybe a corn salsa.  I guess the skys the limit, again use as a base and be creative to your own tastes.

text:
I have mixed feelings about this recipe. I really didn't care for it, and found it quite bland, but my family absolutely loved it -- they gave it five stars.  Tomato-based enchiladas are much more to my taste. However, these reminded me of the white chicken enchiladas they used to serve at Luby's Cafeteria (I never liked those either, but my hubby loved them, go figure).  They were really easy to make. I didn't have any canned peppers -- maybe it would be better with them, if I make these again. I might leave out the cream soup next time and opt for more sour cream and cheese. Thanks so much for this crowd-pleasing recipe.

These were WONDERFUL!  Hub couldn't say enough about them.  The only change I made from reading the reviews was that since we like a lot of flavor, I added 1/2 t. cayenne pepper and 1/2 t. cumin to the sauce before dividing it.  No more/no less for our tastes.  I did only make 3 enchiladas.  As others suggested, to make 6, double the filling.  This is one of those forever keepers.  These are better than any restaurant we've gone to and we've been to some truly fantastic ones ($$$).  Thanks so much!

I decided to try these because I had everything on hand and they looked easy. OMG, my picky 7 year old said this was her new favorite dish, which is huge for me! My husband said this recipe was a definite keeper and my 4 year old even ate them. I made these with corn tortillas instead of flour tortillas and will make them that way again, most likely. I used only half of the green chilis that the recipe called for and used garlic salt instead of garlic powder. They had just the right seasoning and flavor, I thought. I added chicken to the sauce that goes on top because I had some extra and it made these a little heartier that way. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This is okay. Of course I tweaked the recipe a little. I used 1 cup of sour cream and 2 cans of Cream of Mushroom. I added about 1 1/2 cups of prepared rice to the enchiladas because I really like rice. I didnt have any green onions on hand, so I replaced it with onions and green peppers. I also added some hot sauce to the sauce mixture and chopped jalepenos to the top. Also I added an envelope of taco seasoning to the soup/sour cream mixture instead of the chili powder (what ever the spice was). Not too bad, probably will make again.

text:
This recipe came out well for me.  I may have overfilled my enchiladas a bit - the filling only made 5 for me. I followed the recipe exactly.  I think perhaps it could have used a bit more flavor as other reviews mentioned. I would have liked to add some jalapenos for some heat.  Very rich and creamy, but I almost missed the milk in the recipe (it seemed easily missable) and I think the milk (which I didn't measure) made the sauce for the topping just right.  I will make this again on a night when I have left over chicken (I used 4 half breasts and grilled them) just to make it a little quicker to assemble.

text:
This recipe is awesome!  I followed parts of the original and modified it according to what others suggested. Adding the chicken taco seasoning to the meat after it is cubed makes ALL the difference. My office said they could have eaten the chicken just by itself! I also used regular onion instead of green onion because it is what I had on hand. The flavor was fine.  The only other thing I did differently is used fiesta blend cheese and instead of chilis, I used salsa verde. Using the can of salsa verde made this dish even more delicious. If you add more salsa verde, it will be spicier. Great recipe!!!!!

text:
Very tasty!  I made quite a few substitutions, as I did not have certain things on hand or family preferences were taken into consideration.  Also didn't do exact measurements; never do!  I sauted a green bell pepper with 3/4 of a red one 1/2 of a large onion (all sliced), and a couple cloves of fresh garlic (roasted it in olive oil vs butter before adding veggies).  Didn't use green onion or garlic powder or green chiles.  Also used cream of chicken, not mushroom.  Didn't use milk & forgot to reserve sauce before adding chicken & (unmeasured) cheddar.  Served with fresh lettuce & tomato atop!  Turned out great!  Ate as leftovers for a couple days... Enjoy!

text:
These were really yummy, but very, very rich.  When I opened my package of tortillas, I realized they were all cracked in half.  So, I doubled the sauce, used the dish like a lasagna.  I layered 6 tortillas on the bottom, then half the sauce/chicken mixture, 6 more tortillas and the remaining mixture.  Sprinkled the top with cheese and baked for 25 minutes.  I'd make it again, but not too often because of fat content.

text:
These were okay.  My kids really liked them, but my husband and I both thought they could use more chicken and less cheese.  They were very heavy.  My husband actually said you could take a container of nacho cheese sauce, mix it with chicken and get pretty much the same flavor.  Anyway, the only changes I made were to change the cream of mushroom soup to cream of chicken and I added a taco seasoning packet to the sauce.  I think next time I will use this recipe for the filling, but maybe use a green sauce for the topping to make it less heavy.

text:
This was great!  I only changed it a little - I used half of a shallot instead of green onions and added 2 TBSPs of spicey salsa to the shallots one minute before adding the rest of the sauce ingredients.  Also, instead of cheddar cheese, I used a mexican blend of cheeses.  Both the sour cream and cream of mushroom soup were reduced fat and everything was GREAT!  Thanks for a real keeper!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is probably not close to real enchiladas but they are yummy. They are probably delicious if the recipe was followed exactly but I did make some changes based on our preferences. I used  fat free sour cream and 98% fat free cream of chicken soup. I used regular onions instead of green onions. I added some taco seasoning to the chicken when I sauteed it. I added black pepper to the mixture. I'm not a big fan of leftovers but this heats up great. This is a great dish to make on a Sunday and eat throughout the week, or make ahead for a potluck. I've recently added a can each of black beans and corn to the mixture which was a nice addition. I don't like peppers but I bet finely diced red, green or yellow peppers, finely diced, would add some nice color.

text:
Some of the reviewers suggested adding a can of enchilada sauce so that it wouldn't be so dry. As I was making this it appeared dry, so I added half a can to the filling and then the other half I drizzled over the top over the creamy sauce and then sprnkled with cheese. The enchilada sauce also added some needed color. My husband thought this would look good on a buffet table and I agree.

text:
I made these last night but was forced to make a few changes. First, I used cream of chicken soup(I don't happen to like cream of mushroom) and then I realized I had no sour cream on hand, so thinking of an alternative, I used about a 1/4 cup of ranch dressing. I think they came out pretty good. My family loved them. I also used green chile sauce over the top as the soup mixture didn't seem to make enough sauce to cover. Any way, we were pleased with the outcome, and I may just experiment a bit more trying different ways.=)

I made these for company last night and they all loved it. my husband liked it as well, however i though this was a little too creamy. I doubled the sauce like some reviews had suggested and that was way too creamy for my liking. This dish is simple to prepare and has good flavor. Next time I will not use so much sauce. This was very very good. I also doubled the recipe...thank God! That is a must. Though, even though I doubled it I only got 4 tortillas out of it. I also boiled the chicken and then shredded it and mixed it with Taco Seasoning. For the sauce, I added real garlic instead of powdered and some cayanne, salt and hot sauce for some spice. Lastly, I made mexican rice to go along side and decided to put a spoonful of the rice into each tortilla. That was great!

userID:
1463640
Display Name:
BUSYBEE25
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5

0
madeRecipesCount:
77
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/95129.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious recipe. Got Monday morning raves after a Sunday evening dinner even -- and better yet, the raves came from my father in law. I doubled the recipe more or less -- used a Family Size can of cream of chicken instead of mushroom and used half corn and half flour tortillas to suit our combined tastes in the family. Used 6-8" tortillas and it worked well. Added a dash of cumin to the cream sauce and two cans of chiles (one hot, one medium). Don't let the blandness of the sauce from the pan fool you. If you let it sit/simmer a bit, the flavors of the chiles start to show some heat. I garnished with green onions and cheddar cheese. Served with sides of spanish/mexican quinoa and a spicy cole slaw, which was a perfect combination. Highly recommend this recipe. Next steps will be tweaking it over time to be equally delcious, but more nutritious -- the creams and lard-based tortillas are way too heavy to make this dish a regular staple, but for a special occassion it is ideal. I'm always looking for recipes for dinner parties that I can prepare in advance and just casually put in the oven as everyone is chatting over appetizers. This dish definitely fit the bill.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe. I used 2 cups of chicken, and I still only got 2 12" tortillas worth. Also, I used 3 hot serrano peppers instead of milder chilis, and this gave it some kick it might otherwise have been lacking.  I used white onion instead of green (I think green tends to overpower things) and sauteed the peppers along with the onion. If you're like me and don't like mushrooms then don't worry, you can't even tell theres mushrooms in this. Very tasty.
Review:

4

Yummy.    This was so good.   My kids (2 teens, 1 preteen) actually argued over who got the last 2 as leftovers the next day.   I followed the recipe almost exactly. Everyone thought it was better than eating out.

text:
When i read cream of mushroom soup i almost didn't make it since there aren't mushroom lovers in my party. Made it anyway and it was Teriffic! the green chiles didn't make it very spicy at all. I used Kraft "Mexican" blend cheese and it worked fine as a sub for chedder. Also adding a little of the remaining cream of mushroom soup while cooking the chicken (which is not mentioned in the recipe) turned out pretty tender. I will definitely make this again. (oh by the way, the prep time is wrong if you factor in pre-cooking the chicken.)

text:
Eventhough this is a tasty dish I'm only giving it 3 stars.  5 stars to me is OUTSTANDING, and this wasn't.  It was just good.  Also I had to modify the recipe for MY TASTE.  The original recipe for me & hubby was too bland.  To give it more flavor I added tapatio sauce, salsa, cumin, cayenne, etc.  It needed alot of help to taste like it didn't come from a can.  I also doubled the amount of sauce, and used 3 chicken breasts.  My advice is to taste the sauce before mixing in the chicken so you can season it to your liking.  If you do that you wont be disappointed.

region:

country:
None
text:
This dish was good, however, I don't think i'd call it enchiladas.  I think i'd name it creamy chicken burritos. Only because it's missing the traditional sauce, and uses flour tortillas.  It's still very good though.  I would be lying if I said I was rating this recipe 5 stars, but rather, i'm rating my own modification of this, as it is no longer this recipe when you modify it.  I didn't make any drastic changes.  I used cream of chicken soup, jarred pickeled jalapenos instead of chilis, and monterey jack cheese.  For an extra something I threw in some revived dry morels I had laying around.  The dish was very creamy, and had a nice kick to it from the jalapenos.  I prefer flour tortillas to corn, so that didn't bother me at all, and I like the chewy consistency it has.  All in all it was a great dish. *****

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a guideline only and it turned out decent.  Made quite a number of changes:  For starters, I put the chicken in the crockpot with red enchilada sauce on high for about 5 hours and shredded it.  For the last hour, I tossed in some cumin, parsley, chili pepper, and a bay leaf.  As others suggested, I used cream of chicken soup.  I think next time, I would just mix in some sour cream with the chicken and use queso blanco on top.  We have this in the dairy section at my local grocery store and this is what I've had at Mexican restaurants.  I drizzled some of the leftover red enchilada sauce on top before adding the cheese.

text:
Delicious!  I was in a hurry to get these done so I did some pretty strange things.  I only had uncooked chicken breasts so I cut them into cubes and browned them.  Then I threw in a packet of taco seasoning, some hot salsa, and water and let it simmer for a few minutes until I thought they were cooked.  I scooped out the chicken with a little bit of the sauce and proceeded with the recipe as printed.  I loved it -- spicy, creamy, yummy.  Probably too spicy for non-spice lovers but it suited me (an avowed enchilada hater) just fine.

I made this as a last minute dinner. I was going to order out, but realized I didn't stop at an ATM machine. So I logged on to this site, and found this recipe. When I saw that I had all the ingredients, I quickly through it together, and within 45 minutes, it was completely done. My 13yr old daughter and 10 yr old son loved it! I served it with homemade chicken soup that I had left in the refridgerator from a previous dinner, and a quick salad. I was very impressed, because I didn't have to spend a dime, and it was done within the same time I could've had a pizza delivered! But it was a healthier meal, and my kids liked it better then pizza!
Review:
Rating:

This was ok but I doctored it up quite a bit.  I cooked the chicken in taco seasoning, used salsa instead of milk and added a couple jalopenos to it.  Still it was rather bland so we topped it with more salsa.  I also doubled the recipe as many have said to do, and still only had enough filling to make 6 decent sized enchiladas.  As i said we liked what I ended up with but then again, it was quite different than the recipe I started with.

text:
Great recipe!!  I used the flour tortillas, which ended up having a super soft (almost) soggy texture(was still very yummy)...maybe corn tortillas don't have that?  I didnt shred the chicken, merely cut it up into very small pieces and that worked well. I used half milk, half enchilada sauce, cream of chicken soup.... instead of canned chilies used 2 fresh chilies, one half fresh jalepeno and WOW.  Even my extremely picky nearly nine year old niece loved it.  This dish freezes well, too.  Will certainly use this recipe again.  Thank you so much!!!

Great/delicious, very tasty and flavorful. Simple ingredients and quick to put on the table. I made this last night and we loved it. The sauce was made differently than I've made before, without tomatoes or salsa. My kids don't like chili peppers so I used banana peppers instead and the flavor was not as hot as my husband and I like but it was VERY good. I especially like that it was simple and quick to prepare. The only problem was it didn't make enough for seconds, so next time I'll double. I'm sure there won't be any left overs.

text:
After reading all the rave reviews I decided to try this.  I made my chicken the night before by using one lemon and one lime and seasoning lightly with chili powder and ground cumin.

It did not taste quite how I expected but I suspect it was because I used Mozz. and Chedd. cheese combinbed.  Next time I will use only cheddar.  

Also, I added a light drizzle of red enchilada sauce and used half the amount of chilies because one of our little ones is sensitive to spicy food.  The recipe was a real winner in our house!  The youngest seemed to enjoy it most of all.  We also have an elderly relative and it was great for her because she has problems with her dentures so I like to cook soft things that are tasty.

My only comment would be I had a hard time stretching the filling to fill all the shells.  Next time, I will use more chicken.

text:
Excellent recipe!! My folks loved it even my picky dad. my toddler ate some of the chicken which is better than nothing. I followed advice too and used low fat cream of chicken soup. but I also used non fat sour cream, nonfat sharp cheese n the middle and low fat shredded cheddar on the top. skim milk and low fat margarine too and you really cut the fat without losing taste! I added diced tomatoes with green chilies too. VERY yummy!!!

This recipe is great!  These are better than any enchiladas I've ever had in a resteraunt.
Do yourself a favor and add a tsp. of cumin and chile powder and substitute a can of enchilada
sauce for the milk.  I can not image enchiladas without enchilada sauce.  I also used a regular onion
instead of green onion and added some bell pepper. I used cream of chicken soup.  This will
definately become a family favorite.

text:
My family loves this one!  I have made it with canned chicken if I didn't have leftover, I have substituted a 10 oz. can of Ro-tel tomatoes with green chilies drained for the 4 oz. can of green chilies & used cream of chicken soup instead of the mushroom soup...it still tasted great!  I have given the recipe to family & friends...all have loved it.

This was excellent.  We substituted fresh garlic for the garlic powder and added a dash of cayenne pepper to the sauce (for my husband) and a can of chopped black olives.  Delicious.
